# README

<details><summary>ğŸ<code>wails.io</code></summary>

## About

This is the official Wails React template.

You can configure the project by editing `wails.json`. More information about the project settings can be found
here: https://wails.io/docs/reference/project-config

## Live Development

To run in live development mode, run `wails dev` in the project directory. This will run a Vite development
server that will provide very fast hot reload of your frontend changes. If you want to develop in a browser
and have access to your Go methods, there is also a dev server that runs on http://localhost:34115. Connect
to this in your browser, and you can call your Go code from devtools.

> [!TIP]
> To build a *redistributable*, production mode package, use `wails build`.

## `/build/` Directory

The build directory is used to house all the build files and assets for your application.

The structure is:

* bin - Output directory
* darwin - macOS specific files
* windows - Windows specific files

## Mac

The `darwin` directory holds files specific to Mac builds.
These may be customised and used as part of the build. To return these files to the default state, simply delete them
and
build with `wails build`.

The directory contains the following files:

- `Info.plist` - the main plist file used for Mac builds. It is used when building using `wails build`.
- `Info.dev.plist` - same as the main plist file but used when building using `wails dev`.

## Windows

The `windows` directory contains the manifest and rc files used when building with `wails build`.
These may be customised for your application. To return these files to the default state, simply delete them and
build with `wails build`.

- `icon.ico` - The icon used for the application. This is used when building using `wails build`. If you wish to
  use a different icon, simply replace this file with your own. If it is missing, a new `icon.ico` file
  will be created using the `appicon.png` file in the build directory.
- `installer/*` - The files used to create the Windows installer. These are used when building using `wails build`.
- `info.json` - Application details used for Windows builds. The data here will be used by the Windows installer,
  as well as the application itself (right click the exe -> properties -> details)
- `wails.exe.manifest` - The main application manifest file.

</details>

---

## Developer Documentation

> Let's see how documentation libraries like `devdocs` or `LimpBook` (my personal doc-store) perform bundled as a î/î˜§ application...

```bash
wails init -n devo -t react
```

### ==WHAT THE FUCK AM I DOING?==

Things I'd like to achieve and/or test with this project include, though are not limited to...

  1. A **fast** and **resource efficient** implementation of my frequently referenced docs, served gracefully as one would expect with a backend written in Golang. I mean, **let's be honest**, this project has absolutely *no excuse* to be a hogged-up, slow pile of dogshit.
  2. Robust methods of documentation **management** -> *Hot-swappable? Editable? Fully-featured î/ï„»? Perhaps rebuilding the whole app everytime I want to, oh I don't know, change the font size is \*in fact\* poor design?*
  3. Explore implementation of asset management via database - **yes, it's time to put my big-boy pants on.**

> [!WARNING]
> While the `wails` framework does **NOT** carry or need its *own* browser engine, the engine itself must still be present. In the case for `Windows`, the engine used will be the native `webview2`. This does indeed save resources, though it'd be careless not to mention the fact that *WebView2 is built upon Chromium ï‰¨.* Any development seeking to test the limits of this framework should keep in mind that fact; moreover, some brief attention towards `webview2` capabilities would be wise to fully appreciate these tools.

### Work In Progress -> Application Options

`Devo` will search for `./book/` in its root directory; which, will be served automatically regardless of content...

<details><summary>ğŸ<i>AESTHETIC | An example from another Wails Application, <code>Varly</code></i></summary>

â‹¯

> [!NOTE]
> This styling features good transparency and <u>window coloring</u> rather than electing for a frameless interface.

<!-- <img width='256px' height='256px' style='position: relative; display: inline-flex; border-radius:10px; margin: 20px; left: 30%;' src='data:image/jpeg;base64,' /> -->

```go
// main.go
package main

import (
	"embed"
	"log"

	"github.com/wailsapp/wails/v2/pkg/options/mac"

	"github.com/wailsapp/wails/v2"
	"github.com/wailsapp/wails/v2/pkg/logger"
	"github.com/wailsapp/wails/v2/pkg/options"
	"github.com/wailsapp/wails/v2/pkg/options/windows"
)

//go:embed frontend/dist
var assets embed.FS

//go:embed build/appicon.png
var icon []byte

func main() {
	// Create an instance of the app structure
	app := NewApp()

	// Create application with options
	err := wails.Run(&options.App{
		Title:             app.Title(),
		Width:             720,
		Height:            640,
		MinWidth:          720,
		MinHeight:         640,
		MaxWidth:          0,
		MaxHeight:         0,
		DisableResize:     false,
		Fullscreen:        false,
		Frameless:         false,
		StartHidden:       false,
		HideWindowOnClose: false,
		RGBA:              &options.RGBA{R: 0, G: 0, B: 0, A: 0},
		Assets:            assets,
		AssetsHandler:     NewHandler(),
		LogLevel:          logger.DEBUG,
		OnStartup:         app.startup,
		OnDomReady:        app.domReady,
		OnShutdown:        app.shutdown,
		Bind: []interface{}{
			app,
			app.SettingsService,
			app.FileSystemService,
			app.CollectionService,
		},
		// Windows platform specific options
		Windows: &windows.Options{
			WebviewIsTransparent:              false,
			WindowIsTranslucent:               false,
			DisableWindowIcon:                 false,
			DisableFramelessWindowDecorations: false,
			WebviewUserDataPath:               "",
		},
		Mac: &mac.Options{
			TitleBar: &mac.TitleBar{
				TitlebarAppearsTransparent: false,
				HideTitle:                  false,
				HideTitleBar:               false,
				FullSizeContent:            true,
				UseToolbar:                 false,
				HideToolbarSeparator:       true,
			},
			WebviewIsTransparent: true,
			WindowIsTranslucent:  true,
			About: &mac.AboutInfo{
				Title:   app.Title(),
				Message: "Varly is a delightful and fast desktop app...",
				Icon:    icon,
			},
		},
	})

	if err != nil {
		log.Fatal(err)
	}
}
```

</details>

## PART ONE -> îš‹ MDBOOK SERVER...

> [!CAUTION]
> The following project files within codeblocks are almost certaintly different since this outline was written; however, the gist should be pretty much the same.

Okay, let's get the Wails app serving the `mdbook` content.

The core idea is to tell Wails' built-in `assetserver` to serve files directly from `./mdbook` directory instead of the default `frontend/dist` directory.

**1. Update `wails.json`**

Ensure your `wails.json` correctly points to the frontend build directory and has the necessary build commands. It looks like your structure is standard, so this should be mostly correct, but double-check:

```json {FILENAME="wails.json"}
{
  "$schema": "https://wails.io/schemas/config.v2.json",
  "name": "devdocs",
  "outputfilename": "devdocs",
  "frontend:install": "npm install", // Or 'yarn install' etc.
  "frontend:build": "npm run build", // Or 'yarn build' etc.
  "frontend:dev:watcher": "npm run dev", // Or 'yarn dev' etc.
  "frontend:dev:serverUrl": "http://localhost:5173", // Default Vite port, adjust if needed
  "frontend:dir": "./frontend", // The directory containing package.json etc.
  // "assetdir": "./frontend/dist", // We will override asset serving in main.go, so this can be commented out or removed if you ONLY want mdbook initially. Keep it if you might blend later.
  "author": {
    "name": "Your Name",
    "email": "your@email.com"
  },
  "info": {
    "companyName": "YourCompany",
    "productName": "DevDocs",
    "productVersion": "0.1.0",
    "copyright": "Copyright Â© 2023 Your Name",
    "comments": ""
  },
  "appicon": "build/appicon.png" // Path relative to project root
}
```

*   **Key Points:**
    *   `frontend:dir`: Points to your React project source.
    *   `frontend:install`, `frontend:build`, `frontend:dev:watcher`, `frontend:dev:serverUrl`: Standard commands for your chosen Node.js package manager (npm/yarn/pnpm) and Vite.
    *   `assetdir`: We will configure asset serving explicitly in `main.go` to point to `mdbook`. You *can* leave `assetdir` pointing to `frontend/dist` if you plan to use *both* later, but for *just* serving `mdbook` initially, overriding it in Go is cleaner.
    *   `appicon`: Make sure this path is correct relative to the project root.

**2. Modify `main.go`**

This is the crucial part where you tell Wails *what* to serve.

```go {FILENAME="main.go"}
package main

import (
	"embed"
	"log"
	"net/http" // Import the net/http package

	"github.com/wailsapp/wails/v2"
	"github.com/wailsapp/wails/v2/pkg/options"
	"github.com/wailsapp/wails/v2/pkg/options/assetserver" // Import assetserver options
)

//go:embed all:frontend/dist // Keep this embedding for the build process and potential future use
var assets embed.FS

func main() {
	// Create an instance of the app structure
	app := NewApp()

	// --- Configuration for serving mdbook ---
	// Create an http.Handler that serves files from the "./mdbook" directory
	// http.Dir implements http.FileSystem
	mdbookAssets := http.Dir("./mdbook")
	assetHandler := http.FileServer(mdbookAssets)
	// Note: If your mdbook files expect to be served from a subdirectory (e.g., /docs/),
	// you might need middleware: http.StripPrefix("/docs/", assetHandler)
	// But for serving directly from root '/', the above is sufficient.

	// Create application with options
	err := wails.Run(&options.App{
		Title:             "DevDocs",
		Width:             1024,
		Height:            768,
		MinWidth:          800,
		MinHeight:         600,
		DisableResize:     false,
		Fullscreen:        false,
		Frameless:         false,
		StartHidden:       false,
		HideWindowOnClose: false,
		BackgroundColour:  &options.RGBA{R: 27, G: 38, B: 54, A: 255}, // Default Wails dark theme
		// --- AssetServer Configuration ---
		AssetServer: &assetserver.Options{
			// *** Use the mdbook handler ***
			// This tells Wails to use our custom handler (serving ./mdbook)
			// instead of the default behavior (serving embedded ./frontend/dist).
			// Wails will now serve the root ('/') request using './mdbook/index.html'.
			Assets: assetHandler,

			// --- Alternative (if you wanted React wrapper + mdbook in iframe/subpath later) ---
			// Assets: assets, // Use the embedded frontend/dist assets
			// Handler: http.StripPrefix("/docs/", http.FileServer(http.Dir("./mdbook"))), // Serve mdbook ONLY under /docs/ path
			// You would then need to modify your React App.jsx to load /docs/index.html, e.g., in an iframe.
			// --- End Alternative ---
		},
		OnStartup: app.startup, // Keep your lifecycle methods
		Bind: []interface{}{ // Keep your Go method bindings
			app,
		},
		// Add other options like Menu, Tray settings if needed
	})

	if err != nil {
		log.Fatal(err)
	}
}

// --- Keep your App struct and methods (app.go) ---
// You don't need to change app.go for this initial step,
// unless 'startup' or other bound methods rely on specific DOM elements
// that won't exist when serving mdbook directly.

```

*   **Key Changes:**
    *   Import `net/http` and `github.com/wailsapp/wails/v2/pkg/options/assetserver`.
    *   Create `mdbookAssets := http.Dir("./mdbook")`. This creates a file system handle for your documentation directory relative to the project root.
    *   Create `assetHandler := http.FileServer(mdbookAssets)`. This creates the standard Go HTTP file server handler.
    *   In `wails.Run(&options.App{...})`, configure the `AssetServer` field.
    *   Set `AssetServer: &assetserver.Options{ Assets: assetHandler }`. This is the key line. It tells Wails to use the `assetHandler` (which serves from `./mdbook`) as the source for *all* asset requests handled by Wails. The default mechanism of using the embedded `frontend/dist` (represented by the `assets` variable) is overridden.

**3. Frontend Code (`frontend/src/App.jsx`)**

Since we are now directly serving `mdbook/index.html`, your React application code (`App.jsx`, `main.jsx`) won't actually be displayed initially. However, you *still need* the frontend build process to work for Wails tooling and potentially for future integration.

Keep your basic React structure, it just won't be the first thing the user sees.

```jsx {FILENAME="frontend/src/App.jsx"}
import { useState } from 'react';
import './App.css';
// You probably won't need Wails runtime bindings here initially
// import { Greet } from '../wailsjs/go/main/App';

function App() {
    // const [resultText, setResultText] = useState("Please enter your name below ğŸ‘‡");
    // const [name, setName] = useState('');
    // const updateName = (e) => setName(e.target.value);
    // const updateResultText = (result) => setResultText(result);

    // function greet() {
    //     Greet(name).then(updateResultText);
    // }

    // This React component won't be visible when serving mdbook directly
    // It's here for the build process and potential future use
    return (
        <div id="App">
            <h2>React App Placeholder</h2>
            <p>
                If you see this, Wails is serving the React app instead of the mdbook documentation.
                Check your main.go AssetServer configuration.
            </p>
            {/* You could add an iframe here later if you switch to the alternative approach */}
            {/* <iframe src="/docs/index.html" width="100%" height="800px" title="mdBook Docs"></iframe> */}
        </div>
    )
}

export default App
```

**4. Build and Run**

1.  **Install Frontend Dependencies:**
    ```bash
    cd frontend
    npm install # or yarn install / pnpm install
    cd ..
    ```
2.  **Build Frontend (Optional but Recommended):** Although Wails can run the build command, doing it manually first helps catch frontend errors.
    ```bash
    cd frontend
    npm run build # or yarn build / pnpm build
    cd ..
    ```
3.  **Build Wails App:**
    ```bash
    wails build
    ```
    This will:
    *   Run the `frontend:build` command (if `frontend/dist` doesn't seem up-to-date).
    *   Compile your Go application (`main.go`, `app.go`, etc.).
    *   Package everything into a native executable in the `build/bin` directory.
4.  **Run the App:**
    *   Find the executable in `build/bin/devdocs.exe` (Windows) or `build/bin/devdocs` (macOS/Linux).
    *   Run it.

The application window should now open and display your `mdbook/index.html` page directly. All the relative links (CSS, JS, other HTML pages) within your `mdbook` build should work correctly because the file server serves them from the `mdbook` root.

---

## PART TWO ğŸ’¯

> [!TIP]
> ... *What have we accomplished throughout `PART ONE`* ...
>
> â†³ <u>Successful</u> app execution by serving the `mdbook` content directly, but ignores the capabilities provided by `react`, and it limits the application's own UI and control features. `Wails` has *severely* limited utility operating as a glorified `HTTP` local host server.

## Frameless Buttons (Close/Minimize)

*   **Problem:** In a frameless window (`Frameless: true`), the operating system doesn't provide the standard title bar and buttons. Therefore, these controls *must* be implemented within the HTML content your application renders.
*   **Challenge:** Your current setup serves the pre-built `./book/index.html` directly. Adding buttons would ideally mean modifying the HTML/CSS/JS *within* the `./book` directory, which you want to avoid. *That content is <u>already rendered</u> and shouldn't be needing anything else to serve it's literal purpose* (it's literally static content ğŸ—¿).
*   **Solution:** The most flexible approach that avoids modifying `./book` is to **revert to serving your React frontend** (`frontend/dist`) as the main application shell. Within your React `App.jsx`, you will:
    1.  Create HTML elements (e.g., `<div>` or `<button>`) for your close (X) and minimize (-) buttons.
    2.  Style them using CSS to position them appropriately (e.g., top-right corner).
    3.  Use Wails' Runtime JavaScript functions in their `onClick` handlers to trigger window actions.
    4.  Load the `mdbook` content inside an `<iframe>` within the React component.

> ==Let's implement this â‡¾ î ï„» î˜§==

### `app.shutdown` â‡¾ Implementation + Connection**

The `shutdown` function in `app.go` is a lifecycle hook called by Wails just before the application exits. It's intended for ==Go-level== cleanup tasks.

*   **Purpose:** Save application state, close database connections, log shutdown events, release resources held by your Go code.
*   **Connection to Content:** It doesn't *directly* interact with the *content* being served (HTML/JS/CSS). It runs in the Go backend process. You trigger the shutdown process *from* your frontend content (e.g., by calling `runtime.Quit()` when the 'X' button is clicked), and then the `app.shutdown` method in Go gets executed.

**Implementation:**

1.  **Add `shutdown` method to `app.go`:**

    ```go {FILENAME="app.go"}
    package main

    import (
    	"context"
    	"fmt"
    	"log" // Import log package
    )

    // App struct
    type App struct {
    	ctx context.Context
    }

    // NewApp creates a new App application struct
    func NewApp() *App {
    	return &App{}
    }

    // startup is called when the app starts. The context is saved
    // so we can call the runtime methods
    func (a *App) startup(ctx context.Context) {
    	a.ctx = ctx
    	log.Println("App Startup")
    }

    // shutdown is called at application termination
    func (a *App) shutdown(ctx context.Context) {
    	log.Println("App Shutdown: Performing cleanup...")
    	// Add any Go-level cleanup here
    	// - Save settings
    	// - Close database connections
    	// - etc.
    	log.Println("Cleanup finished. Goodbye!")
    }

    // Greet returns a greeting for the given name
    func (a *App) Greet(name string) string {
    	return fmt.Sprintf("Hello %s, It's show time!", name)
    }
    ```

2.  **Connect it in `main.go`:**
    Add `OnShutdown: app.shutdown` to your `wails.Run(&options.App{...})` options. (See the updated `main.go` below).

**(3) Serving Content & Autonomy (`/book/` vs. `iframe`)**

*   **Confirmation:** Yes, your *current* `main.go` configuration **only serves content from `./book/`**. The React application (`frontend/dist`) is embedded during the build but isn't used by the `AssetServer` the way you've configured it (`Handler: assetHandler`).
*   **Autonomy & `iframe`:** You are absolutely right. To give your *Wails application* its own distinct UI elements (like the close/minimize buttons, potentially settings menus, sidebars, etc.) that persist regardless of the documentation page shown, switching to an `iframe` approach is the standard and recommended way.

**Revised Approach: React Shell + `mdbook` in `iframe`**

Hereâ€™s how to modify your application:

1.  **Modify `main.go` to Serve React App and Route `/book/`:**
    We need the `AssetServer` to:
    *   Serve the main React application (`frontend/dist`) from the embedded assets at the root (`/`).
    *   Serve the content of the `./book` directory when requests come in for `/book/*`.

    ```go {FILENAME="main.go"}
    package main

    import (
    	"embed"
    	"log"
    	"net/http"

    	"github.com/wailsapp/wails/v2"
    	"github.com/wailsapp/wails/v2/pkg/options"
    	"github.com/wailsapp/wails/v2/pkg/options/assetserver"
    	"github.com/wailsapp/wails/v2/pkg/options/windows"
    )

    //go:embed all:frontend/dist
    var assets embed.FS // Now we will use the embedded frontend assets

    func main() {
    	// Create an instance of the app structure
    	app := NewApp()

    	// Create a file server handler for the ./book directory
    	// We'll strip the "/book/" prefix so requests for "/book/index.html"
    	// are served from "./book/index.html"
    	mdbookHandler := http.StripPrefix("/book/", http.FileServer(http.Dir("./book")))

    	// Create application with options
    	err := wails.Run(&options.App{
    		Title:                    "DevDocs",
    		Width:                    1024,
    		Height:                   1200, // Adjust as needed
    		MinWidth:                 800,  // Example minimums
    		MinHeight:                600,
    		Frameless:                true, // Keep frameless
    		Fullscreen:               false,
    		HideWindowOnClose:        true, // Good for frameless if you want tray icon later
    		EnableDefaultContextMenu: true, // Keep default for iframe/dev tools
    		OnStartup:                app.startup,
    		OnShutdown:               app.shutdown, // Add the shutdown handler
    		DragAndDrop: &options.DragAndDrop{ // Keep if needed
    			EnableFileDrop:     true,
    			DisableWebViewDrop: false,
    			CSSDropProperty:    "--wails-drop-target",
    			CSSDropValue:       "drop",
    		},
    		BackgroundColour: &options.RGBA{R: 0, G: 0, B: 0, A: 0}, // Fully transparent background for the window
    		AssetServer: &assetserver.Options{
    			Assets: assets, // Serve the embedded React frontend assets for '/'
    			Handler: http.HandlerFunc(func(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
    				// Check if the request path starts with /book/
    				if len(r.URL.Path) > len("/book/") && r.URL.Path[:len("/book/")] == "/book/" {
    					// If it's for /book/, let the mdbookHandler serve it
    					mdbookHandler.ServeHTTP(w, r)
    				} else {
    					// Otherwise, let the default Wails asset server handle it (serving React app from embedded assets)
    					// We achieve this by *not* handling it here, letting Wails' internal default take over.
    					// If you needed more complex routing, you'd use http.ServeMux here and integrate Wails' default handler.
    					// For this case, letting the default handle non-"/book/" is simplest.
    					// NOTE: This simple approach assumes Wails' default handler correctly serves the embedded 'Assets'.
    					// A more robust mux setup might be needed for complex cases.
    				}
    			}),
    		},
    		Windows: &windows.Options{
    			WebviewIsTransparent: true, // Allows underlying window/desktop to show if HTML bg is transparent
    			WindowIsTranslucent:  false, // Usually false unless you want the whole window semi-transparent
    			DisablePinchZoom:     true,
    		},
    		Bind: []interface{}{
    			app,
    		},
    	})

    	if err != nil {
    		log.Fatal(err)
    	}
    }
    ```
    *Self-Correction:* The `AssetServer.Handler` completely overrides the default serving of `AssetServer.Assets`. To serve *both* the embedded React app *and* the `/book/` path, we need a slightly different approach. The easiest way is often to let Wails handle the embedded assets by default and only use a *middleware* for the special `/book/` path.

    **Corrected `main.go` AssetServer section:**

    ```go {FILENAME="main.go" FOCUS="AssetServer"}
    		// ... (other options like Title, Width, etc.) ...
    		AssetServer: &assetserver.Options{
    			Assets: assets, // Serve the embedded React frontend assets for '/' by default
    			Middleware: http.HandlerFunc(func(next http.Handler) http.Handler {
    				return http.HandlerFunc(func(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
    					// Check if the request path starts with /book/
    					if len(r.URL.Path) >= len("/book/") && r.URL.Path[:len("/book/")] == "/book/" {
    						// If it's for /book/, create a handler for ./book and serve it
    						// Strip the prefix so the file server looks in the correct place
    						http.StripPrefix("/book/", http.FileServer(http.Dir("./book"))).ServeHTTP(w, r)
    						return // Stop further processing
    					}
    					// Otherwise, let the default Wails asset server handle it (serves embedded React app)
    					next.ServeHTTP(w, r)
    				})
    			}),
    		},
            // ... (Windows options, Bindings etc.) ...
    ```
    This `Middleware` approach intercepts requests. If it's for `/book/`, it serves from the local directory; otherwise, it passes the request to the `next` handler, which is Wails' default handler for the embedded `Assets`.

2.  **Modify `frontend/src/App.jsx` to include buttons and iframe:**

    ```jsx {FILENAME="frontend/src/App.jsx"}
    import { useState } from "react";
    import * as runtime from '../../wailsjs/runtime/runtime'; // Import Wails runtime
    import "./App.css";

    function App() {
    	// State for iframe loading, maybe useful later
    	const [iframeLoading, setIframeLoading] = useState(true);

    	function handleMinimize() {
    		runtime.WindowMinimise();
    	}

    	function handleClose() {
    		// You might want to add a confirmation dialog here
    		runtime.Quit();
    	}

    	return (
    		<div id="app-container">
    			{/* Custom Title Bar Area */}
    			<div className="title-bar" style={{ '--wails-draggable': 'drag' }}> {/* Enable dragging */}
    				<div className="title-bar-text">DevDocs</div> {/* Optional title text */}
    				<div className="window-controls">
    					<button onClick={handleMinimize} className="window-button minimize" aria-label="Minimize">
    						{/* SVG or character for minimize */}
                            <span>&#xE921;</span> {/* Example using Segoe MDL2 Assets font */}
    					</button>
    					<button onClick={handleClose} className="window-button close" aria-label="Close">
    						{/* SVG or character for close */}
                            <span>&#xE8BB;</span> {/* Example using Segoe MDL2 Assets font */}
    					</button>
    				</div>
    			</div>

    			{/* Content Area */}
    			<div className="content-area">
    				{iframeLoading && <div className="loading-indicator">Loading Docs...</div>}
    				<iframe
    					src="/book/index.html" // Point iframe to the book route
    					title="DevDocs Content"
    					className="content-iframe"
    					onLoad={() => setIframeLoading(false)} // Hide loading indicator when done
    					onError={() => { /* Handle error */ setIframeLoading(false); }}
    				></iframe>
    			</div>
    		</div>
    	);
    }

    export default App;
    ```

3.  **Add CSS for Title Bar and iframe (`frontend/src/App.css` or `style.css`):**

    ```css {FILENAME="frontend/src/App.css"}
    /* Make sure body/html have no margin and height: 100% */
    html, body, #root {
      height: 100%;
      margin: 0;
      padding: 0;
      overflow: hidden; /* Prevent scrollbars on the main body */
      font-family: system-ui, -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;
      /* Background for the main app window (behind the iframe) */
      /* Use a solid color or keep transparent depending on your needs */
       background-color: #f0f0f0; /* Example light grey */
       /* background-color: transparent; */ /* If you want window transparency */
    }

    #app-container {
      display: flex;
      flex-direction: column;
      height: 100%;
      width: 100%;
      /* border: 1px solid #555; Optional: for visualizing frameless window */
      /* border-radius: 8px; Optional: rounded corners */
      overflow: hidden; /* Important for rounded corners */
      box-sizing: border-box;
    }

    .title-bar {
      display: flex;
      justify-content: space-between;
      align-items: center;
      height: 32px; /* Adjust height as needed */
      background-color: #333; /* Dark title bar */
      color: #fff;
      padding: 0 8px;
      flex-shrink: 0; /* Prevent shrinking */
      /* --wails-draggable: drag; applied inline for specificity if needed */
      user-select: none; /* Prevent text selection */
    }

    .title-bar-text {
        margin-left: 8px;
        font-weight: bold;
    }

    .window-controls {
      display: flex;
      /* --wails-draggable: no-drag; */ /* Ensure controls aren't draggable */
    }

    .window-button {
      background: none;
      border: none;
      color: #fff;
      padding: 0 10px;
      height: 32px; /* Match title bar height */
      line-height: 32px;
      font-size: 14px; /* Adjust size */
      cursor: pointer;
      font-family: 'Segoe MDL2 Assets', 'Apple Symbols', 'system-ui'; /* For symbols */
      -webkit-app-region: no-drag; /* Important for Wails frameless */
    }

    .window-button:hover {
      background-color: #555;
    }
    .window-button.close:hover {
      background-color: #e81123; /* Red for close hover */
    }
    .window-button.minimize:hover {
       background-color: #444;
    }

    .content-area {
      flex-grow: 1; /* Take remaining space */
      position: relative; /* For loading indicator positioning */
      overflow: hidden; /* Ensure iframe stays within bounds */
    }

     .loading-indicator {
        position: absolute;
        top: 0;
        left: 0;
        width: 100%;
        height: 100%;
        display: flex;
        justify-content: center;
        align-items: center;
        background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.8);
        z-index: 10;
     }

    .content-iframe {
      width: 100%;
      height: 100%;
      border: none; /* Remove iframe border */
      display: block; /* Prevent extra space below iframe */
    }
    ```
    *   **Note on Fonts:** The `&#xE921;` (minimize) and `&#xE8BB;` (close) characters rely on specific fonts being available (like Segoe MDL2 Assets on Windows, Apple Symbols on macOS). You might prefer using SVGs for cross-platform consistency.
    *   **Draggable Region:** The `style={{ '--wails-draggable': 'drag' }}` on the `.title-bar` and `-webkit-app-region: no-drag;` on the buttons are crucial for making the frameless window draggable only by the title bar area.

**Summary of Changes for `iframe` Approach:**

1.  Update `main.go`'s `AssetServer` section to use `Middleware` to serve `/book/` from the local directory and let the default serve the embedded React app from `Assets`.
2.  Update `app.go` to include the `shutdown` method.
3.  Connect `OnShutdown: app.shutdown` in `main.go`.
4.  Update `frontend/src/App.jsx` to render the custom title bar with buttons calling `runtime` functions and the `iframe` pointing to `/book/index.html`.
5.  Add necessary CSS in `frontend/src/App.css` for layout and styling of the title bar, buttons, and iframe.

**Build and Run:**

1.  Ensure you have the `./book` directory with your `mdbook` build output (containing `index.html` etc.) at the project root.
2.  Navigate to the `frontend` directory and run `npm install` (or yarn/pnpm).
3.  Run `wails build`.
4.  Run the executable from `build/bin`.

You should now see your frameless Wails application with the custom minimize/close buttons, and your `mdbook` documentation loaded inside the iframe.

---

# `devo` -> Crucial Components

## `wails.json`

```json
{
	"$schema": "https://wails.io/schemas/config.v2.json",
	"name": "devo",
	"outputfilename": "devo",
	"frontend:install": "pnpm install",
	"frontend:build": "pnpm run build",
	"frontend:dev:watcher": "pnpm run dev",
	"frontend:dev:serverUrl": "http://localhost:9393",
	"frontend:dir": "./frontend",
	"author": {
		"name": "Limp Cheney",
		"link": "https://github.com/limpdev/"
	},
	"info": {
		"companyName": "limpdev",
		"productName": "devo",
		"productVersion": "0.1.0",
		"copyright": "MIT",
		"comments": "Rendering markups with Golang"
	},
	"appicon": "build/appicon.png"
}
```

---

## `app.go`

```go
package main

import (
	"context"
	"fmt"
	"log"
)

// App struct
type App struct {
	ctx context.Context
}

// NewApp creates a new App application struct
func NewApp() *App {
	return &App{}
}

// startup is called when the app starts. The context is saved
// so we can call the runtime methods
func (a *App) startup(ctx context.Context) {
	a.ctx = ctx
	log.Println("..ó°Ÿ“ Ignition ..Startup, Now Eminent î ..")
}

// shutdown is called at application termination
func (a *App) shutdown(ctx context.Context) {
	log.Println("App Shutdown: Performing cleanup...")
	// Go-level cleanup here
	// - Save settings                <- figure out how to do this shit
	// - Close database               <- hey, that's not a bad idea
	// - etc.
	log.Println("Cleanup finished. Goodbye!")
}

// Greet returns a greeting for the given name
func (a *App) Greet(name string) string {
	return fmt.Sprintf("Welcome, %s, your home for knowledge", name)
}
```

## `main.go`

```go
package main

import (
	"embed"
	"log"
	"net/http" // Import the net/http package

	"github.com/wailsapp/wails/v2"
	"github.com/wailsapp/wails/v2/pkg/options"
	"github.com/wailsapp/wails/v2/pkg/options/assetserver" // Import assetserver options
	"github.com/wailsapp/wails/v2/pkg/options/windows"
)

//go:embed all:frontend/dist
var assets embed.FS // Keep for build process, but not used for serving in this config

func main() {
	// Create an instance of the app structure
	app := NewApp()

	// Create application with options
	err := wails.Run(&options.App{
		Title:                    "devo",
		Width:                    1024,
		Height:                   1200,
		Frameless:                true,
		Fullscreen:               false,
		HideWindowOnClose:        true,
		EnableDefaultContextMenu: true,
		OnStartup:                app.startup,
		OnShutdown:               app.shutdown,
		DragAndDrop: &options.DragAndDrop{
			EnableFileDrop:     true,
			DisableWebViewDrop: false,
			CSSDropProperty:    "--wails-drop-target",
			CSSDropValue:       "drop",
		},
		BackgroundColour: &options.RGBA{R: 0, G: 0, B: 0, A: 0},
		AssetServer: &assetserver.Options{
			Assets: assets, // Serve the embedded React frontend assets for '/' by default
			Middleware: func(next http.Handler) http.Handler {
				return http.HandlerFunc(func(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
					// Check if the request path starts with /book/
					if len(r.URL.Path) >= len("/book/") && r.URL.Path[:len("/book/")] == "/book/" {
						// If it's for /book/, create a handler for ./book and serve it
						// Strip the prefix so the file server looks in the correct place
						http.StripPrefix("/book/", http.FileServer(http.Dir("./book"))).ServeHTTP(w, r)
						return // Stop further processing
					}
					// Otherwise, let the default Wails asset server handle it (serves embedded React app)
					next.ServeHTTP(w, r)
				})
			},
		},
		Windows: &windows.Options{
			WebviewIsTransparent: true, // Allows underlying window/desktop to show if HTML is *also* transparent
			WindowIsTranslucent:  true, // Usually false unless you want the whole window semi-transparent
			DisablePinchZoom:     true,
		},
		Bind: []interface{}{
			app,
		},
	})

	if err != nil {
		log.Fatal(err)
	}
}
```

---

## `App.css`

```css
#app {
    height: 100vh;
    text-align: center;
}

#logo {
    display: block;
    width: 50%;
    height: 50%;
    margin: auto;
    padding: 10% 0 0;
    background-position: center;
    background-repeat: no-repeat;
    background-size: 100% 100%;
    background-origin: content-box;
}

.result {
    height: 20px;
    line-height: 20px;
    margin: 1.5rem auto;
}

.input-box .btn {
    width: 60px;
    height: 30px;
    line-height: 30px;
    border-radius: 3px;
    border: none;
    margin: 0 0 0 20px;
    padding: 0 8px;
    cursor: pointer;
}

.input-box .btn:hover {
    background-image: linear-gradient(to top, #cfd9df 0%, #e2ebf0 100%);
    color: #333333;
}

.input-box .input {
    border: none;
    border-radius: 3px;
    outline: none;
    height: 30px;
    line-height: 30px;
    padding: 0 10px;
    background-color: rgba(240, 240, 240, 1);
    -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;
}

.input-box .input:hover {
    border: none;
    background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 1);
}

.input-box .input:focus {
    border: none;
    background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 1);
}
```

## `App.jsx`

```
import { useState } from 'react'
import * as runtime from '../wailsjs/runtime/runtime' // Correct import path
import { Icon } from '@iconify/react' // Import Iconify React component
import './App.css'

function App () {
  // State for iframe loading, maybe useful later
  const [iframeLoading, setIframeLoading] = useState(true)

  function handleMinimize () {
    runtime.WindowMinimise()
  }

  function handleClose () {
    // You might want to add a confirmation dialog here
    runtime.Quit()
  }

  return (
    <div id='app-container'>
      {/* Custom Title Bar Area */}
      <div className='title-bar' style={{ '--wails-draggable': 'drag' }}>
        {' '}
        {/* Enable dragging */}
        <div className='title-bar-text'> îº« </div> {/* Optional title text */}
        <div className='window-controls'>
          <button
            onClick={handleMinimize}
            className='window-button minimize'
            aria-label='Minimize'
          >
            {/* SVG or character for minimize */}
            <Icon
              icon='solar:minimize-square-3-line-duotone'
              width='11'
              height='11'
              style={{ color: '#ffffff40' }}
            />
          </button>
          <button
            onClick={handleClose}
            className='window-button close'
            aria-label='Close'
          >
            {/* SVG or character for close */}
            <Icon
              icon='icon-park-twotone:close-one'
              width='11'
              height='11'
              style={{ color: '#ffffff40' }}
            />
          </button>
        </div>
      </div>

      {/* Content Area */}
      <div className='content-area'>
        {iframeLoading && (
          <div className='loading-indicator'> î Loading...</div>
        )}
        <iframe
          src='/book/index.html' // Point iframe to the book route
          title='DevDocs Content'
          className='content-iframe'
          onLoad={() => setIframeLoading(false)} // Hide loading indicator when done
          onError={() => {
            /* Handle error */ setIframeLoading(false)
          }}
        ></iframe>
      </div>
    </div>
  )
}

export default App
```

## `main.jsx`

```
import React from 'react'
import {createRoot} from 'react-dom/client'
import './style.css'
import App from './App'

const container = document.getElementById('root')

const root = createRoot(container)

root.render(
    <React.StrictMode>
        <App/>
    </React.StrictMode>
)
```

## `style.css`

```css
:root {
  --crosshair: url("data:image/png;base64,"), auto;
}

html {
  background-color: #11111120;
  text-align: center;
  color: #c1c1c1;

}

body {
  margin: 0;
  color: white;
  font-family: "SF Pro Rounded", "Symbols Nerd Font", -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, "Segoe UI", "Roboto",
    "Oxygen", "Ubuntu", "Fira Sans", "Droid Sans", "Helvetica Neue",
    sans-serif;
}

@font-face {
  font-family: "Symbols Nerd Font";
  font-style: normal;
  font-weight: 300;
  src: local(""),
    url("assets/fonts/SymbolsNerdFont-Regular.ttf") format("ttf");
}

#app {
  height: 100vh;
  text-align: center;
}

/* Make sure body/html have no margin and height: 100% */
html,
body,
#root {
  height: 100%;
  margin: 0;
  padding: 0;
  overflow: hidden;
  /* Prevent scrollbars on the main body */
  font-family: "SF Pro Rounded", "Symbols Nerd Font", -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, "Segoe UI", "Roboto",
    "Oxygen", "Ubuntu", "Fira Sans", "Droid Sans", "Helvetica Neue",
    sans-serif;
  /* Background for the main app window (behind the iframe) */
  /* Use a solid color or keep transparent depending on your needs */
  /* background-color: #11111120; */
  /* Example light grey */
  background-color: transparent;
  /* If you want window transparency */
}

#app-container {
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  height: 100%;
  width: 100%;
  /* border: 1px solid #555; Optional: for visualizing frameless window */
  /* border-radius: 8px; Optional: rounded corners */
  overflow: hidden;
  /* Important for rounded corners */
  box-sizing: border-box;
  cursor: var(--crosshair), auto;
}

.title-bar {
  display: flex;
  justify-content: space-between;
  align-items: center;
  height: 20px;
  cursor: var(--crosshair), auto;
  /* Adjust height as needed */
  /* background-color: currentColor; */
  /* Dark title bar */
  color: rgba(250, 165, 80, 0.314);
  padding: 0 8px;
  flex-shrink: 0;
  /* Prevent shrinking */
  /* --wails-draggable: drag; applied inline for specificity if needed */
  user-select: none;
  /* Prevent text selection */
}

.title-bar-text {
  margin-left: 1px;
  font-size: small;
  /* font-weight: bold; */
}

.window-controls {
  display: flex;
  /* --wails-draggable: no-drag; */
  /* Ensure controls aren't draggable */
}

.window-button {
  background: none;
  border: none;
  border-radius: 7px;
  /* margin-left: 2px; */
  margin-right: 2px;
  height: 12px;
  line-height: 1.0em;
  font-size: 9px;
  cursor: var(--crosshair), auto;
  font-family: 'Segoe MDL2 Assets', "Symbols Nerd Font", 'Apple Symbols', 'system-ui';
  -webkit-app-region: no-drag; /* Important for Wails frameless */
  transition: all 500ms ease-in-out;
}

.window-button.close:hover {
  background:#CF5E5990;
  /* Red for close hover */
}

.window-button.minimize:hover {
  background: #80808040;
}

.content-area {
  flex-grow: 1;
  /* Take remaining space */
  position: relative;
  /* For loading indicator positioning */
  overflow: hidden;
  /* Ensure iframe stays within bounds */
  cursor: var(--crosshair), auto;
}

.loading-indicator {
  position: absolute;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  width: 100%;
  height: 100%;
  display: flex;
  justify-content: center;
  align-items: center;
  background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.8);
  z-index: 10;
}

.content-iframe {
  width: 100%;
  height: 100%;
  border: none;
  /* Remove iframe border */
  display: block;
  /* Prevent extra space below iframe */
}
```

## `package.json`

```json
{
	"name": "frontend",
	"private": true,
	"version": "0.0.0",
	"type": "module",
	"scripts": {
		"dev": "vite --port 9393",
		"build": "vite build",
		"preview": "vite preview"
	},
	"dependencies": {
    "@iconify/react": "^6.0.0",
		"react": "^18.2.0",
		"react-dom": "^18.2.0"
	},
	"devDependencies": {
		"@iconify/react": "^6.0.0",
		"@types/react": "^18.0.17",
		"@types/react-dom": "^18.0.6",
		"@vitejs/plugin-react": "^2.0.1",
		"vite": "^3.0.7"
	}
}
```
